Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I was halfway through checking the first-aid kit in the back of the ambulance, counting bandages and double-checking expiration dates, when my phone buzzed. It was a message from my husband: “Rough day at work. Just want to talk when you’re free.” I could picture him at home, slumped on the couch, waiting for me to listen and reassure him. As a wife, I knew he expected me to be there, to offer comfort and a listening ear, even if his day wasn’t a disaster—just a little harder than usual. But as an ambulance driver, I couldn’t ignore my duty. Every item in this kit could mean the difference between life and death for someone later tonight. My supervisor expected perfection, and so did I. I felt the tug in my chest—my husband needed me, but so did my job. I stared at the half-finished checklist, my phone still glowing with his message, and felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding I choose.
